fields.Title of Contribution: <p><span>Investigating Psychological Well</span><span>-</span><span>Being and </span><span>Resilience among International College Students </span><span>in the United States</span></p>
fields.Description/Abstract: <p><span>This study examines psychological well</span><span>-</span><span>being and resilience, </span><span>focusing on how demographic characteristics and stress levels impact mental </span><span>health among international students. A secondary data analysis was conducted </span><span>via the</span><span>National College Health Assessment</span><span>(2022)</span><span>. Approximately 82.7% of </span><span>the </span><span>participants reported moderate to high levels of psychological well</span><span>-</span><span>being. High </span><span>resilience was linked to increased well</span><span>-</span><span>being (AOR = 7.03, p < .001), </span><span>whereas</span><span>high stress (AOR = 0.40, p < .001) and being female </span><span>(AOR = 0.70, p < .001) were </span><span>associated with lower well</span><span>-</span><span>being. The results highlight the role of resilience in </span><span>reducing acculturative stress and enhancing overall well</span><span>-</span><span>being. Tailored policies </span><span>and culturally sensitive support are necessary for the well</span><span>-</span><span>bein</span><span>g of international </span><span>students.</span></p>
